title: Letters: Voluntary super betrays low-paid workers
text:
We’re flying blind in the power market

Re: ‘‘Electricity market fails to drive steady supply’’, (October 1). What’s missing in the NEM is a comprehensive, transparent information system – although hard to believe, we’re actually flying blind. Congested transmission lines and lack of second-by-second information from the distribution systems that actually pipe electricity to consumers, many of whom add to the growing lack of stability by pumping solar back into networks, are the root cause of the lamentable state of the NEM. Not solving the information system and making up for this by planning fast start-up generation is putting the cart before the horse.

Distribution networks should no longer be seen as predictable load centres; they are dynamic and therefore information and control systems that were once intended only for the generation and transmission sectors, now have to be extended to include distribution networks. They have to be integrated with AEMO control systems to provide an essentially seamless, second by second view of the entire NEM, thus providing in due course the basis for stability based on learning experiences.

Phil Kreveld

Power Parameters

Westmeadows, Vic

Keep opinion right out of the news pages

The Financial Review is managing better than most newspapers to maintain the quality of its reporting. One concerning trend however, is the placement of biased opinion pieces in the News section.

A case in point is Aaron Patrick’s article on the NDIS (‘‘Government and budget can’t afford limitless NDIS scheme’’, September 30). Loaded language such as “well-meaning doctors”, and “fostering the belief”, mark the piece as an opinion and disqualify it as reporting.

Mention of a “lesbian suffering multiple sclerosis”, even though her sexual orientation is irrelevant to the case, was nothing more than smirking titillation.

That aside though, I did admire the boldness of Mr Patrick’s claim that a program with a $4.6 billion underspend is a “long-term threat to the budget” that “will be impossible to control “.

Mitchell Browne

Blaxland, NSW

Low rates put a second GFC in the frame

Paul Singer and Ray Dalio (chief executives of billion-dollar investment companies), Mohamed El-Erian (chief economic adviser at Allianz), Warwick McKibbin (former RBA board member), Adrian Blundell-Wignall (former OECD director) and Satyajit Das (former banker, economic analyst and author) have all criticised central banks for minimising cash rates.

Minimal and even increasing negative interest cash rates have failed in Japan and OECD countries.

The public endure minimal interest, or no-interest deposit accounts and the low dollar value will increase import prices. Personal debt is growing unsustainably to over over 200 per cent per annual income. Home prices and share prices are becoming excessive, increasing wealth inequality.

Some people will be tempted to increase their debt levels and investment risks if the cash rate is minimised. Are we headed for the GFC mark II?

Advertisement

Graham McPherson

Mandurah, WA

Blame the megabrains for WeWork’s issues

Media and analysts seem to want us to conclude that chief executive Adam Neumann was at the centre of everything wrong with WeWork.

The real culprit is an investing environment where stars like Masayoshi Son of Softbank and the big boys running large institutions have a compulsion to raise mega funds, make mega fees, generate alpha returns, lead mega IPOs and master the universe!

Neumann is just their mascot.

Chetan Shah

Beecroft, NSW

Stop muddying the waters on China policy

Labor’s current overtures to Beijing are, at best, unhelpful (“Political split over China”, October 1).

For foreign policy to be effective, it needs to be authoritative, unequivocal, and a country has to speak with one voice. Our relationship with China is of utmost importance and must be conducted with clarity and mutual respect. Labor’s intervention muddies the waters to an extent where that is at risk.

Michael Schilling

Millswood, SA
